Comments:

195-201

  • By using the dimensionless ratio, we can easily compare the fundamental features of the cylinder equation using only one parameter. If instead we plotted E vs z, we would need to plot the equation for many values of R and h to understand the full range shapes the equation can have.\htmlnewline

    202

  • As h/R decreases, the cylinder solution approaches the ring solution. For h/R=0.1, the lines for the ring and cylinder cannot be distinguished by eye.\htmlnewline

    203

  • For h/R=1, the cylinder and ring curves increasingly overlap starting at approximately z/R=1. This means the cylinder field is becoming more and more like the ring field as z/R increases, which is expected.\htmlnewline

    204

  • The ring and cylinder curves (for h/R=1) overlap with the point charge curve for large z/R. This is expected because both being to â€œlookâ€ like a point charge as you move away from them.\htmlnewline

    205

  • The explanation for the curve approaching zero as r/R increases is in this limit, the cylinder appears to be â€œlongâ€. Inside of an infinitely long cylinder h/Râ†’âˆž, the field is zero (even offâ€“axis). This can be shown by using Gaussâ€™s law.\htmlnewline

    206

  • All curves have odd symmetry (E(âˆ’z)=âˆ’E(z)), as expected â€“ the field for z>0 is positive and the field for z<0 is negative. (The image below only shows z/R>0.)\htmlnewline \htmlnewline \htmlnewline %

2.2 Checking Gaussâ€™s Law

212

Given a point charge Q at the origin, compute the electric flux Î¦Eâ€‹=âˆ«Eâ‹…dA through one face of a cube that is also centered on the origin using Coulombâ€™s law and explicit evaluation of the integral.

214
%

Solution

From Gaussâ€™s law, the net flux through any closed surface is Qenclâ€‹/Ïµoâ€‹. The net flux through the cubeâ€™s surface is Q/Ïµoâ€‹, and the flux must be the same through each face, so we expect the answer to be Q/6Ïµoâ€‹. In this problem, you are being asked to show that you get the same result without using Gaussâ€™s law.

Several students solved for case when cube was not centered on the origin but rather had one corner at the origin and edges along the cartesian coordinate axes. In this case, one can conclude the flux through one face should be Q/24Ïµoâ€‹. This is equivalent to asking if we split the given cube into 8 subâ€“cubes, what is the flux through the outer face of one of the sub-cubes. In this case, the face area of the subâ€“cube is 1/4 of the area of the main cube. In addition to being the wrong problem, the solution given does not use Coulombâ€™s law and explicit evaluation of the integral. (The motivation for this problem is to reinforce the idea that Gaussâ€™ law holds for arbitrary surfaces and as practice for setting up integration.)

In general,

r=xx^+yy^â€‹+zz^. If we assume the side length is 2a, then for the top side, r=xx^+yy^â€‹+az^.

We need to evaluate

Î¦Eâ€‹=âˆ«topâ€‹Eâ‹…dA

Using

E=kqr3râ€‹ and dA=dxdyz^, the integral is

Î¦Eâ€‹=kqâˆ«âˆ’aaâ€‹dyâˆ«âˆ’aaâ€‹a2+x2+y2â€‹3/2adxâ€‹

or, nondimensionalizing the integral using xâ†’x/a and yâ†’y/a,

Î¦Eâ€‹=kqâˆ«âˆ’11â€‹dyâˆ«âˆ’11â€‹1+x2+y2â€‹3/2dxâ€‹

Defining b2=1+y2 and using Wolfram Alpha for the integration, we have

Î¦Eâ€‹=kqâˆ«âˆ’11â€‹dy(1+y2)2+y2â€‹2â€‹

Using Wolfram Alpha, Î¦Eâ€‹=kq(2Ï€/3)=q/6Ïµoâ€‹. %

2.3 Charge on Concentric Thick Shells

249

Charge placed on concentric spherical conducting shells, the crossâ€“section of which is shown. Both shells have a thickness of t. The inner shell has an outer radius of a and a net charge of âˆ’Q. The outer shell has an inner radius of b and a net charge of +Q. Assume that Q is positive.

251
253

Using Gaussâ€™s law and the fact that the electric field inside a conductor must be zero show that

255

  1. there can be no charge on the inner surface of the inner conductor,

    257-258

    Answer: A Gaussian sphere with a surface inside the inner conductor has E=0 on its surface (b/c E inside a conductor is zero). Based on âˆ®Eâ‹…dl=Qenclâ€‹/Ïµoâ€‹, this implies Qenclâ€‹=0. (Note that all charges must be on the surface of a conductor, so the only possible location for the charge is on the inner and outer surfaces.)

    259

  2. the charge on the inner surface of the outer conductor is +Q, and

    261-262

    Answer: A Gaussian sphere with its surface inside the outer conductor has E=0 on its surface (b/c E inside a conductor is zero). Based on âˆ®Eâ‹…dA=Qenclâ€‹/Ïµoâ€‹, this implies Qenclâ€‹=0. The charge on the inner conductor was given as âˆ’Q. To make the charge inside the Gaussian sphere zero, we need +Q on the inner surface of the outer conductor to get Qenclâ€‹=0.

    263

  3. there is no charge on the outer surface of the outer conductor.

    265-266

    Answer: If the total charge on the outer conductor is +Q and all of it is on its inner surface, but conservation of charge, there is no charge on its outer surface. Recall that charges arrange themselves on a conductor to make the electric field inside all conductors zero. With this charge arrangement, the field due to the charges on the outer surface of the inner conductor cancels the field due to the charge on the inner surface of the outer conductor for r>b.

    267

  4. Find the electric field in each of the five labeled regions and sketch a plot of E/(kQ/a2) versus r/a. Region 1. is the empty volume inside of the inner conductor, region 2. is the inner conductor, region 3. is the empty volume between the conductors, region 4. is the outer conductor, and region 5. is the region outside of the outer conductor. (Hint: Use Gaussâ€™s law several times; when not zero, the electric field should be proportional to 1/r2.)

    269-270

    Answer: 1. E=0 2. E=0 3. E/(kQ/a2)=âˆ’1/(r/a)2 4. E=0 5. E=0

    271

6.3 Ampereâ€™s law

641

The figure shows the crossâ€“section of two square planes that are â€œlargeâ€, meaning that their side length is much larger than t. A surface current of K=Koâ€‹z^ flows on the bottom plane (Koâ€‹ has units of Amps/meter); the top plane has a surface current of K=âˆ’Koâ€‹z^. (To understand a surface current, think of it as being created by placing many long straight wires sideâ€“byâ€“side; in the diagram, the wires would be perpendicular to the page.)

643

Use Ampereâ€™s law to find the magnetic field for all y. Justify all of your steps. Note that most of the steps involve starting with the most general solution, B(x,y,z)=Bxâ€‹(x,y,z)x^+Byâ€‹(x,y,z)y^â€‹+Bzâ€‹(x,y,z)z^, and making symmetry arguments such that integration in Ampereâ€™s law is not needed.

645
647

Answer

649

If one considers the sheets to be composed straight wires, then one can argue that any field must be in the x direction - at any point in space, there are two wires whose field sums to horizontal (use the Biot-Savart result that for an infinite wire, the field is tangent to a circle centered on the wire; make sure that you can draw a diagram that justifies this claim).

651

As a result, B(x,y,z)=Bxâ€‹(x,y,z)x^. If the system is infinite in the x and z directions, there can be no dependence on these coordinates, so B(x,y,z)=Bxâ€‹(y)x^.

653

At this point, we can use Ampereâ€™s law. Although it is possible to use Ampereâ€™s law twice on the given system, it is easier to find the field due to one of the sheets and then use superposition.

655
657

âˆ®Bâ‹…dl=Î¼oâ€‹Ienclâ€‹=âˆ«1â€‹Bâ‹…dl+âˆ«2â€‹Bâ‹…dl+âˆ«3â€‹Bâ‹…dl+âˆ«4â€‹Bâ‹…dl

659

The sign of Ienclâ€‹ depends on the direction of integration around the Amperian loop. Choosing clockwise integration, Ienclâ€‹=+Koâ€‹d, where d is the width of the Amperian loop. (The sign of Ienclâ€‹ is positive if you wrap your fingers around loop in the direction of integration and the flow of current through the loop is in the direction of your thumb.)

661

Therefore, we are left with

663

Î¼oâ€‹Ienclâ€‹=âˆ’B2â€‹(y)w+B4â€‹(y)w

665

where we have assumed the unknown B2â€‹ and B4â€‹ are in the positive x direction. It may seem we are stuck, but we can argue that B2â€‹=âˆ’B4â€‹, that is the field a distance above the sheet must be equal in magnitude and opposite in sign to the field the same distance below the sheet.

667

The final result is that the field is Î¼oâ€‹Koâ€‹/2x^ above the blue sheet and âˆ’Î¼oâ€‹Koâ€‹/2x^ below the sheet.

669

Finally, we can use superposition to conclude that the field is âˆ’Î¼oâ€‹Koâ€‹x^ between the sheets and zero otherwise.

As an example of solving two ODES, in the following, I solve the two equations

numerically using the Forward Euler approximation. In this approximation, the equations can be rewritten as

I use the parameter Î”t=0.01, which controls the accuracy of the solution. (Note that the Forward Euler approximation is not a good method for solving ODEs, but it is simple and easy to implement.)

MATLAB

707
function ode_demo()
1
2
    %% Forward Euler
3
    dt = 0.01;
4
5
    t = 0;
6
    x(1) = 1;
7
    y(1) = 1;
8
    Nsteps = 100;
9
10
    fprintf('t\tx\ty\n')
11
    for i = 1:Nsteps-1
12
        fprintf('%.1f\t%.1f\t%.1f\n',t(i),x(i),y(i));
13
        x(i+1) = x(i) + dt*x(i);
14
        y(i+1) = y(i) - dt*y(i);
15
        t(i+1) = t(i) + dt;
16
    end
17
18
    plot(x,y);
19
    hold on;
20
    xlabel('x')
21
    ylabel('y')
22
    title('$dx/dt=x; dy/dt=-y$; x(0)=y(0)=1','Interpreter','Latex');
23
24
    %% Runge-Kutta
25
26
    function ret = dXdt(t, X)
27
        % For MATLAB ODE functions, must specify code that computes right-hand
28
        % side of differential equations. Here we have
29
        % dx/dt = x
30
        % dy/dt = -y
31
        %
32
        % Defining X = [x, y], in matrix notation
33
        %   dX/dt = [x; -y]
34
        ret = [X(1); -X(2)];
35
    end    
36
37
    [t, X] = ode45(@dXdt, [0, 1], [1, 1]);
38
39
    plot(X(:,1),X(:,2),'r-');
40
41
    legend('Forward Euler', 'Runge-Kutta 4-5');
42
end
